review_blob: Very weak by many mile high brewed IPAs . Almost reminds me of a cheap knock off of ryeteous ipa. If I didnt know where the two brews were made I may be slightly suspicious. This canned pint of dank reminds me of ryeteous from sept. 2012 being distributed . Very rye oriented late hopped ipa with very one dimensional hops - may I say one trick pony ? I can say the basis of this beer could go somewhere - time to leave it in the hands of Bill Eye to improve it . Oh wait - 7cs was not that good to dry docks IIPA - Dougs a way better IPA brewer. Hope doing this Beer on that expensive copper brew rig works out- better stick to hefes and chads sours. Nice try! ( p. s. I cant tell you how many Highlanders lost their Marbels tasting this in prosts tasting room . Ha! Times will be -a- changing  when the mile high city makes a pliney adversary . This isnt it tho .

Acquired a bomber at mile high wine & spirits  in Lakewood , CO. 

Poured into a goblet glass . First impression is the smell- this beer smells like a hoppy pack of juicy fruit!!!! Beautiful golden yellow hue that is really intriguing . First sips remind me of a west coast styled double IPA that is very one dimensional . It has very nice balance between grapefruit & pine but not much else. Good for a Pliny lover in need of a good  IIPA but no substitute .

beautiful belgian styled ale that has amazing aromas of mild butterscotch and raisins. the taste is a beautiful smooth dark fruit flavor with hints of burnt caramel. nice hint of roasted malts. finishes nice with a mild dry clean palate.

750ML wire caged bottle. popped with a roor! lots of carbination, served in Delirium Tremens tulip. pours a beautiful warm yellow that is crystal clear aside from a little reminant yeast. aroma is very sweet and malty, well rounded smell. taste is very malty & sweet with a very nice fruitiness. slight bubblegum flavor on the ending flavor. leaves the tongue dry and waiting for more. one of my favorites.

750ml wire caged bottle. cork popped off with a lot of force, great carbonation in this one! pours a deep ruby red color, with a beautiful white head that provided excellent lacing in my goblet. first flavor is a sort of malty-bubblegum that transitioned into a semi citrusy mid flavor. the finish to me was dry and slightly minty, very interesting. left a nice semi-sour sweet flavour on the tongue. one of the most interesting brews I have had in a while.

750ML wire caged bottle. cork popped with very little force compared to some other Belgians. pours a dark brown/red color with a little haziness from the yeast from bottle re-fermentation. nice off white head, medium carbonation. the flavor is nice and malty balanced with a fruity-currant  flavor. leaves the tongue nice and semi-wet, versus excessively dry. overall I thought it was very digestable, and had some character to it. versus other quads this one is very smooth and could be served to non belgian beer lovers.

honestly stopped by this place with a couple of buddys one night and ended up falling in love with this stout. very rich, chocolatey flavour with a dry finish. huge tan head with excellent lacing, very smooth but with a amazing flavor. best stout brewed in colorado(at least that I have tasted so far!) MAD PROPS to the brewer at Ironworks, Ill stop by sometime to thank you in person.

from a 75ci bottle. cork popped with a little umph behind it.  pours a beautiful dark brown with hues of red throughout. head starts out a little thick, with a lovely velvet texture to it. it keeps the velvety head through out . flavor is malty with a little roast character to it. very nice. also has slight hints of caramel throughout, but nothing too in your face . very well done. also has a semi dry finish that sneaks up on ya, and leaves your palate with a sort of dancing sweet sourness. awesome, very different then the first time I tried this.

bottled. pours a beautiful straw yellow with a little haze to it. , beautiful white head that is very vigorous at the pour, but settles out to be a light and lacey. beautiful aromas I expect to smell with a belgian single- malty with a slight acidic tone with a little bit of fruityness- usually giving off scents of apple & pear.  flavor starts out refreshing and clean, then transcends into the same flavors as the aroma. nice semi dry finish, leaving a beautiful bitter flavor on the palate. one of my favorite beers from Russian River yet.

750ML wire caged bottle , bought @ mile high wine & spirits. cork popped off with a blast, lots of C02 in this beer. poured into chimay goblet.  pours a pale light yellow with the thickest white head anyone could ask for. very robust, vigorous carbination tickles your nose as you drink this beer. aromas of banana & crisp malt. flavorr is very much the same, with a mildly sweet finish. very crisp palate afterward. one of my favorite Belgians.

on tap @ falling rock tap house. pours a rusty deep orange. piney citrusy hops smells throughout. very bitter but elaborate IPA. very thick dense white head that lasts throughout a pint glass. has a slight noticable oak finish that leaves your tongue nice an dry. one of my favorite IPAs.

on tap @ Falling rock tap house. Denver, CO. pours a deep yellow/orange color. aroma is a very piny-citrusy combo with beautiful hop floral notes throughout. definitley was worth waiting for! taste was very piney-grapefruity hops balances transcending into a very citrusy piney fusion. very delectable. hides the alcohol almost completely. 

very good beer overall. something i wish was available more often. come on vinnie!

tried both out of the bottle several times & tried on tap @ falling rock tap house. pours a hazey straw yellow with white head, excellent lacing. 

smell is of citrusy piney hops. very nice aroma, something I would sell everyday if possible. 

first taste is about the same, but tends to exhibit grapefruity mid flavors. usually it always finishes smooth out of the bottle, but I have noticed out of the tap really showcases a strong bitter finish. that seems to be the only  real difference between tap and bottle. overall, one of my favorite IIPAs.

22oz Bomber, new Avery Labeling. poured into Chimay goblet.  completely trasnlucent to the eye with a dark ruby red color. thin white head with minimal lacing. tastes of sweet candi syrup , also molasses like. very little fruit character to the beer.

purchased @ applejack liqours. pours a dark orange almost red color. beautiful white head with moderate lacing. first sip was intensely orange/citrus flavored with a smooth malt backbone. definitely a favorite of mine from Oskar Blues.

very good pale ale done up by oskar blues. when I first drank this beer, I almost mistook it for a IPA, just for the insane amount of hops it possesses. golden orange color, centiennial hops finish out with a dry finish. very good beer.

very diverse scottish inspired ale. not too strong, I dont think this would fit the 90 shilling in taxes. but does encompass a lot of maltiness found in a lot of scottish ales. not even my favorite from colorado.
this beer is a good companion to have around for when budweiser drinkers come over. very bland attributes for a wheat beer, but right up the alley of your domestic lager drinker.
probibly the best thing in NBBs line up.  smokey and malty like guiness, but  with a slight sweetness. almost like an odd porter. not my cup of fermented goodness

one of the best brews NBB has come out with to date. I liked a lot of stuff they produced, but as my tastes changed, so did my love for NBB. out of everything they produce, Ill buy this to drink on hot, summer afternoons where thicker beers would be just too thick. there is a time and place for everything, and mothership wits place is in the middle of summer.

available in bottles/kegs/cans. I personally have drunken a lot of this stuff, and the flavor to me has changed a lot since I started drinking. I used to like the biscuit malt balance this beer had, but now its just watered down rubbish. this is a beer i think I am going to get the recipe (original recipe, as long as the ingredients are still available), and brew. NBB has production in mind.

poured into tulip glass for tasting. upon uncapping the bottle, the tremendous volume of co2 rolled out with a swoosh. slowly poured into my tulip( I have heard reports of aggressive pours making 5+ finger heads). pours a beautiful dark golden orange color with hoppy notes and brett in the aroma. taste is very balanced malt to hop profile, leaning more toward the maltier side of the equation. no attributed extreme sour character from the brett, very well accented. the lingering palate left on the tongue is semi-dry, and a slight bit tart as well. second trappist product ever consumed.

375ml bottle corked & wire caged. batch 004x4. corked popped aggressively with no foaming.beer served at about 45*F. beer served in snifter glass. beer poured a beautiful deep brown with ruby red hues. first smells give off a lovely sour carmelized fruit scent. the smell is sharp but well rounded at the same time. acidity notes throughout . first tastes are initially very sour with sweet fruit flavors, transcending into beautiful mild acidic tones. truely a nice sour ale ! one of my top favorites!

upon purchasing this beer, the first thing I noticed is the larger then usual bottle. the picture on the front encompassed a curious gnome working in what looks to be a hop field. interesting. 

I pop the top and pour a glass into a cold pint glass. the first thing I notice is the slightly skunky-fruit essence coming off the poured beer. the appearence is a cloudy yellow reminiscent of a fine belgium  tripel. upon sipping, the first thing I notice is the slightly watery mouth feel this ale posses in comparison to many ales with an OG of 1092.  

the palate is imediately very dry and clean, with a nice rounded out after flavor of citrusy hops. the sweetness of the beer then showed up right about the time the hops hit the palate. 

I put down the glass after  a nice sized gulp  and the first thing I notice is the nice and foamy lacing left after each sip. once the beer is finished, your glass will have a nice set of rings left over, very pretty. 

the flavor left on the back of my palate is very sweet and hoppy and is very citrusy. 

truely a beer that shows the rich tradition of brewing  Belgium has.  I liked it so much, I brewed NBs clone just to have a simular beer around when the time is right.
